pulls.title: References and minor tweaks
pulls.author: yaroslavros
pulls.body: Added some references and few minor suggestions.

comments.body:
I don't believe there is such a thing as an "HTTP/3 request".

```suggestion
An H3-WT connection can carry HTTP requests with any method, scheme, authority, and path.  These values are not constrained by any similar values that may have applied to the WebTransport session itself.  For example, if the Listener endpoint is "https://my-origin.example.com/wt", this does not limit the origins to which requests may be sent on the H3-WT connection.
```

This is an interesting idea, but the WebTransport session interface doesn't provide an exported authenticator, so I don't see how it can work.

Notably, WebTransport-HTTP/3 defines a special pseudo-TLS-exporter for each session, but WebTransport-HTTP/2 does not.

If I understand things correctly the only gap is WebTransport over HTTP/2 with TLS 1.2 that has not negotiated Extended Master Secret extension.
I wonder if we ever see any clients/servers that support WebTransport over HTTP/2 that won't negotiate Extended Master Secret...
Perhaps worth bringing this question on webtrans WG meeting?

I'm happy to drop this sentence for now.

draft-ietf-webtrans-overview says "individual transport protocols MAY expose TLS-based authentication capabilities such as client certificates", so I think we could possibly fix this by saying "If the WebTransport protocol exposes a TLS exported authenticator capability, ...".  However, this poses two problems:
1. It's not clear whether WebTransport-HTTP/2 can be said to expose such a capability.
2. The W3C WebTransport API doesn't expose it anyway, because the API tries to match the general abstract session interface.

This does seem like a good topic for WEBTRANS.  In the meantime, we can keep this sentence with a note about when it can be used, or drop it.

pulls.title: Inject explicit Stream IDs
pulls.author: bemasc
pulls.body:
WebTransport does not provide access to the underlying stream IDs. Unless WebTransport is changed to expose these stream IDs (and require transports to define linearly increasing stream IDs), we need to inject our own.

The cost of <=4 bytes per request is tolerable.  The bigger annoyance here is that it prevents us from recapitulating HTTP/3 exactly as H3-WT over QuicTransport.

comments.author: yaroslavros
comments.body:
Careful computation of available MTU taking into account all the nested VarInts can be very annoying and error prone. And some encapsulations need to do things like TCP MSS clamping which can go horribly wrong if computed incorrectly.

Let's keep this for the time being but I'm really hopeful we will be able to resolve it more gracefully by exposing relevant Stream ID from underlying QUIC or WebTransport Capsule.

comments.author: bemasc
comments.body:
> Careful computation of available MTU taking into account all the nested VarInts can be very annoying and error prone.

Perhaps, but I don't think this PR changes that in any way.  Whether stream IDs are provided in-band (this PR) or exposed by the API, HTTP/3 will still need to write the Quarter Stream ID into each Datagram. WebTransport Datagrams are bound to the WebTransport Session, not any WebTransport Stream.

> Let's keep this for the time being but I'm really hopeful we will be able to resolve it more gracefully by exposing relevant Stream ID from underlying QUIC or WebTransport Capsule.

I hope so too, but I wonder if there's someone out there who wants to support WebTransport protocols that don't naturally support (monotonic) Stream IDs.
